instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> solder won't stick
threads.message:
Hi,
have a MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with liquid spill and burn marks at <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> intermittent power. The number 1 pad is burnt I removed the resistor noticed it connects to many many things.
Problem is can't get solder to stick to that pad. I used flux and solder then scraped a little but is not showing any conductivity. Is there any way to fix this?
Thanks Much

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> solder won't stick
threads.message: Pin 1 simply connects to 3V42, you can run a wire to 3V42 anywhere on the board <CAPACITOR>C5120</CAPACITOR> seems like a good place to get it.
